symptoms: Olive-green or brown spots on leaves, fruit, and twigs.
Leaves may become twisted and puckered.
Fruit lesions become black, corky, and may crack.
Infected leaves often drop prematurely.
Apple Scab.cause: Caused by the fungus Venturia inaequalis, which thrives in cool, wet spring weather. The fungus overwinters in infected leaves on the ground and releases spores during spring rains.

organic: Clean up and destroy fallen leaves in the autumn to reduce overwintering spores.
Prune trees to improve air circulation and allow leaves to dry faster.
Apply sulfur or copper-based fungicides starting in early spring before blossoms open.
chemical: Apply fungicides containing Captan or Myclobutanil according to package directions, especially during wet periods from bud-break until mid-summer.

symptoms: Firm, brown to black spots on fruit, which may enlarge in a concentric ring pattern.
Infected fruit shrivels into a black 'mummy'.
Small, purple spots on leaves that enlarge to form 'frogeye leaf spot'.
Reddish-brown, sunken cankers on branches.
Apple Black Rot.cause: Caused by the fungus Diplodia seriata (previously Botryosphaeria obtusa). It infects dead wood, cankers, and mummified fruit, releasing spores during wet weather.

organic: Prune out dead or diseased branches and cankers during winter dormancy.
Remove and destroy all mummified fruit from the tree and the ground.
Maintain tree health with proper watering and fertilization to resist infection.
chemical: Apply fungicides like Captan or Thiophanate-methyl from silver tip through harvest, especially after events that cause wounds (like hail or pruning).

symptoms: Small, cinnamon-brown, powdery pustules on both upper and lower leaf surfaces.
Pustules are oval or elongated and scattered across the leaves.
Can also appear on stalks and husks in severe cases.
Corn Common Rust.cause: Caused by the fungus Puccinia sorghi. Spores are carried by wind over long distances. It's favored by cool temperatures (16-23Â°C) and high humidity.

organic: Plant resistant corn hybrids, which is the most effective management method.
Avoid dense planting to promote air circulation and reduce humidity within the crop canopy.
chemical: Foliar fungicides (e.g., containing Pyraclostrobin, Azoxystrobin) can be effective if applied early when rust is first detected, especially on susceptible hybrids.

symptoms: Large, dark brown to black lesions on leaves and stems, often appearing water-soaked.
A white, fuzzy ring of fungal growth may appear on the underside of leaves at the lesion edge, especially in humid conditions.
Tubers develop a reddish-brown, dry, firm rot under the skin.
Potato Late Blight.cause: Caused by the water mold Phytophthora infestans. It thrives in cool, moist conditions. Spores are spread by wind and rain from infected plants or cull piles.

organic: Ensure good air circulation and water the soil, not the foliage.
Prophylactically apply copper-based fungicides before symptoms appear, especially when cool, wet weather is forecast.
chemical: Apply fungicides containing Chlorothalonil or Mancozeb. Alternate between different fungicide groups to prevent resistance. Begin applications before disease onset.

symptoms: Large, dark, water-soaked spots on leaves that turn brown/black.
White fungal growth may appear on the undersides of leaves.
Stems develop large black lesions.
Fruit develops large, firm, greasy-looking, dark brown spots.
Tomato Late Blight.cause: Same as Potato Late Blight (Phytophthora infestans). It spreads rapidly in cool, wet weather and can destroy an entire crop in a short time.

organic: Remove and destroy infected plants immediately (do not compost).
Ensure wide spacing for air circulation.
Apply copper-based fungicides or bio-fungicides (Bacillus subtilis) preventatively.
chemical: Apply protectant fungicides like Mancozeb or Chlorothalonil before the disease starts. Curative fungicides may be needed in a severe outbreak.

symptoms: Stunting of the plant.
Upward cupping, yellowing, and curling of leaves.
Leaves become smaller and may feel leathery.
Significant reduction in flower and fruit production.
Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus.cause: A virus (TYLCV) transmitted exclusively by the silverleaf whitefly. The whitefly acquires the virus by feeding on an infected plant and then transmits it to healthy plants.

organic: There is no cure for an infected plant; it must be removed and destroyed immediately to prevent spread.
Control whiteflies by using reflective mulch (silver plastic) or introducing beneficial insects like lacewings.
Use floating row covers on young plants to prevent whiteflies from reaching them.
Spray with insecticidal soap or neem oil to manage whitefly populations.
chemical: Control of the whitefly vector is key. Use systemic insecticides containing Imidacloprid on young, non-fruiting plants. For fruiting plants, use insecticides like spiromesifen.
